text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
SABAH
- The Islamist-led government will definitely fall either by the withdrawal of the conservative party in the coalition or toppled by a censure motion, the newspaper said.
HURRIYET
- Leftist opposition leader, Bulent Ecevit, says the nightmare is over as the Islamist-led government is about to go.
- The Turkish union of chambers of commerce has called on parliament to save the country from the current political instabality.
MILLIYET
- President Suleyman Demirel has warned Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan not to draw the Turkish armed forces into politics.

- The stock exchange watchdog began monitoring investment by Islamist groups in accordance with the decision taken by military-dominated National Security Council (MGK) to crack down on Islamist activism.
YENI YUZYIL
- The head of the Turkish army Ismail Hakki Karadayi swears to protect the secularist state.
RADIKAL
- Opposition parties and dissident MPs from the conservative wing of the ruling coalition are preparing to present a censure motion to topple the government.
CUMHURIYET
- Around 50,000 Turkish troops stepped up cross-border operations to northern Iraq to support the Kurdistan Democratic Party's fight against Kurdistan Workers Party.
DUNYA
- Philips has entered the Turkish mobile phone market.
- Onion prices saw record rises in the last 12 months, rising from 2,000 to 3,000 lira per kg last year to the current 140,000 lira per kg.
ZAMAN
- A three-way deal has been signed by Turkey, Iran and Turkmenistan to build a natural gas pipeline to carry Turkmen natural gas via Iran to Turkey.
